standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Interpret multiplying fraction and whole number word problems

question.content: Over a one week period each person in the Taylor family eats $\dfrac34$ of a box of cereal. There are  $5$ people in the family.  **How many boxes of cereal does the Taylor family eat in one week?**

hints.content: Each person eats $\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ of a box of cereal.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to sixteen-fourths with tick mark at every one-fourth unit. There is a red dot and label at three-fourths.

hints.content: There are  $\blueD{5}$ people in the family who eat cereal.   [[☃ image 1]]    We can multiply $\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ to figure out how many boxes of cereal the Taylor family needs for one week.

images.alt: A number line showing zero-fourths to an unlabeled unit with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. There is a red label at three-fourths. Below the number line, a blue arrow jumps 5 times, stopping at every three-fourths unit beginning at zero-fourths and ending at a question mark.

hints.content: $\blueD{5 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac34}=\dfrac{\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD3} {\maroonD4}={\dfrac{15}{4}}$
The Taylor family needs between $3$ and $4$ boxes of cereal for one week.

question.content: Leonardo uses $\dfrac23$ of a bottle of green paint to paint each picture of a forest.  He plans to paint $5$ pictures of forests.  **How many bottles of green paint will Leonardo use?**

hints.content: Each picture requires $\green{\dfrac{2}{3}}$ of a bottle of green paint. Leonardo plans to paint $\blue{5}$ pictures.  Picture $\blue1$ | Picture $\blue2$  | Picture $\blue3$ |Picture $\blue4$ | Picture $\blue5$ :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  ||||  We can multiply $\blue{5} \times\green{\dfrac23}$ to figure out how many bottles of green paint he will use.

images.alt: Rectangle divided into three equal sized parts with two parts shaded green. Rectangle is labeled two-thirds.
Rectangle divided into three equal sized parts with two parts shaded green. Rectangle is labeled two-thirds.
Rectangle divided into three equal sized parts with two parts shaded green. Rectangle is labeled two-thirds.
Rectangle divided into three equal sized parts with two parts shaded green. Rectangle is labeled two-thirds.
Rectangle divided into three equal sized parts with two parts shaded green. Rectangle is labeled two-thirds.

hints.content: $\quad{\blue{5} \times} \green{\dfrac23}$  $=\dfrac{{\blue{5} \times }\:\green 2} {\green3}$  $={\dfrac{10}{3}}$
Leonardo will use between $3$ and $4$ bottles of green paint.

question.content: There are $6$ people in Eden's family. Each person drinks $\dfrac25$ of a liter of milk each week.  **How many liters of milk does Eden's family drink each week?**

hints.content: Each person drinks $\maroonD{\dfrac25}$ of a liter each week. We want to know how much $\blueD6$ people drink.    Person $\blueD1$ | Person $\blueD2$  | Person $\blueD3$ |Person $\blueD4$ | Person $\blueD5$ | Person $\blueD6$ :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  |||||  We can multiply $\blueD6 \times\maroonD{\dfrac25}$ .

images.alt: Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.
Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.
Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.
Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.
Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.
Rectangle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded pink. Rectangle is labeled two-fifths.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}{\blueD6 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac25}\\\\ &=\dfrac{{\blueD6 \times }\:\maroonD2} {\maroonD5}\\\\ &={\dfrac{12}{5}}\\\\ &={2\dfrac{2}{5}} \end{align}$
Eden's family drinks between $2$ and $3$ liters of milk each week.

question.content: A salmon fish eats $\dfrac32$ kilograms of krill in one week.   **How many kilograms of krill would a salmon eat in $3$ weeks?**

hints.content: A salmon fish eats $\maroonD{\dfrac32}$ kilograms of krill in one week.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to ten-halves with tick marks every one-half unit and labels every two-halves unit. There is a pink dot and labeled at tick mark three-halves.

hints.content: We want to find how many kilograms of krill a salmon fish eats in  $\blueD{3}$ weeks.   [[☃ image 1]]    We can multiply $\blueD{3 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac32}$ to figure out how many kilograms of krill a salmon eats in $\blueD3$ weeks.

images.alt: A number line showing zero-halves to an unlabeled unit with tick marks at every one-half unit. There is a pink label at three-halves. Below the number line, a blue arrow jumps 3 times, stopping at every three-halves unit beginning at zero-halves and ending at a question mark.

hints.content: $\blueD{3 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac32}=\dfrac{\blueD{3 \times}\maroonD3} {\maroonD2}={\dfrac{9}{2}}$
A salmon will eat between  $4$ and $5$ kilograms of krill in $3$ weeks.

question.content: For a science experiment, each group is given $\dfrac{11}8$ liters of purple liquid.   **How many liters are needed for $3$ groups?**

hints.content: Each group gets $\purpleD{\dfrac{11}8}$ liters of purple liquid. We want to know the total amount of liquid for $\blueD3$ groups.  Group $\blueD1$ | Group $\blueD2$  | Group $\blueD3$  :-: |:-: |:-:  |  |    We can multiply $\blueD{3} \times\purpleD{\dfrac{11}8}$ to figure out how many liters of purple liquid are needed.

images.alt: A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with all parts shaded purple. Under this rectangle is the label eight-eighths. Above this rectangle is the label Group 1.
A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with three parts shaded purple. Under the rectangle is the label three-eighths. It is also under the label of Group 1.
A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with all parts shaded purple. Under this rectangle is the label eight-eighths. Above this rectangle is the label Group 2.
A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with three parts shaded purple. Under the rectangle is the label three-eighths. It is also under the label of Group 2.
A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with all parts shaded purple. Under this rectangle is the label eight-eighths. Above this rectangle is the label Group 3.
A rectangle divided into eight equal parts with three parts shaded purple. Under the rectangle is the label three-eighths. It is also under the label of Group 3.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{3 \times} \purpleD{\dfrac{11}{8}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{3 \times}\purpleD{11}} {\purpleD8}\\\\ &={\dfrac{33}{8}}\\\\ &=4\dfrac{1}{8} \end{align}$
Between  $4$ and $5$ liters of purple liquid are needed for $3$ groups.

question.content: Leah knit a scarf that is $130$ centimeters $(\text{cm})$ long.  Theo knit a scarf that is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ as long as Leah's scarf.  **How long is Theo's scarf?**

hints.content: Leah's scarf is $\purpleD{130\,\text{cm}}$ long.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 200 with tick marks at every ten units and labels every 50 units. There is a purple dot and label at 130.

hints.content: Theo's scarf is $\dfrac{4}{3}$ as long.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\purpleD{130}\times \dfrac{4}{3}$ to find out how long Theo's scarf is.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of unequal lengths. The top bar is shaded green and divided into 4 parts, each part labeled one-third of 130. The bottom bar is aligned on the left with the top bar and is shaded purple. It is divided into 3 parts the same size as the parts in the top bar, each part labeled one-third of 130. It is shorter than the top bar. Below the bars, is a number line labeled 0 to 200 with tick marks at every ten units. Tick marks are labeled from left to right: 0, 50, 100, 130, 150, and 200. There is a purple dot and label at 130 and a green dot and a question mark at around 173.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\purpleD{130} \times \dfrac{4}{3}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{130} \times 4}{3}\\\\ &=\greenE{\dfrac{520}{3}} \end{align}$
$=\greenE{173\dfrac{1}{3}}$
Theo's scarf is between $173\,\text{cm}$ and $174\,\text{cm}$ long.

question.content: Marcus bought a rug that is  $6$ meters $(\text{m})$ long.  Vinny bought a rug that is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ as long as Marcus's rug.  **How long is Vinny's rug?**

hints.content: Marcus's rug is $\purpleD{6\,\text{m}}$ long.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled 0 to 10 with labeled tick marks every 1 unit. There is a purple dot and label at tick mark 6.

hints.content: Vinny's rug is $\dfrac{3}{4}$ as long.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\purpleD{6}\times \dfrac{3}{4}$ to find out how long Vinny's rug is.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars of unequal lengths. The top bar is divided into 3 equal parts, each labeled one-fourth of 6. All parts are shaded green. The bottom bar is longer and is divided into 4 equal parts, each part labeled one-fourth of 6. All parts are shaded purple. Below the bars is a number line labeled 0 to 10, with a labeled tick mark every 1 unit. There is a purple dot on tick mark 6. There is a green dot labeled question mark between tick marks 4 and 5.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\purpleD{6} \times \dfrac{3}{4}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{6} \times 3}{4}\\\\ &=\greenE{\dfrac{18}{4}} \end{align}$
$=\greenE{4\dfrac{1}{2}}$
Vinny's rug is between $4\,\text{m}$ and $5\,\text{m}$ long.

question.content: Charles biked  $\dfrac23$ of a kilometer yesterday. He biked $7$ times as far today.  **How many kilometers did Charles bike today?**

hints.content: Charles biked $\maroonD{\dfrac23}$ of a kilometer yesterday.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to fifteen-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. Labels are at tick marks zero-thirds, three-thirds, six-thirds, nine-thirds, twelve-thirds and fifteen-thirds. Tick mark two-thirds is labeled in pink with a pink dot.

hints.content: He biked $\blueD{7}$ times as far today.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{7 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac23}$ to figure out how far Charles biked today.

images.alt: A number line showing zero-thirds to an unlabeled unit with tick marks at every one-third unit. There is a pink label at two-thirds. Below the number line, a blue arrow jumps 7 times, stopping at every two-thirds unit beginning at zero-thirds and ending at a question mark.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueD{7 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac23}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{7 \times}\maroonD2} {\maroonD3}\\\\ &={\dfrac{14}{3}}\\\\ &=4\dfrac{2}{3} \end{align}$
Charles biked between $4$ and $5$ kilometers today.

question.content: $5$ friends each have $\dfrac34$ of the money needed to a buy a bag of popcorn at the movie theatre.  **What is the largest number of bags they can buy?**

hints.content: There are $\blue5$ people. Each person  has $\green{{\dfrac34}}$ of the money needed for one bag.  Person $\blue1$ | Person $\blue2$  | Person $\blue3$ | Person $\blue4$ | Person $\blue5$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   | | | |   We can multiply $\blue5 \times\green{\dfrac34}$ to figure out how many bags they can buy.

images.alt: Rectangle divided  into four equal-sized parts with three parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled three-fourths.
Rectangle divided  into four equal-sized parts with three parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled three-fourths.
Rectangle divided  into four equal-sized parts with three parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled three-fourths.
Rectangle divided  into four equal-sized parts with three parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled three-fourths.
Rectangle divided  into four equal-sized parts with three parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled three-fourths.

hints.content: $\quad{\blue5 \times} \green{\dfrac34}$  $=\dfrac{{\blue5 \times }\:\green 3} {\green4}$  $={\dfrac{15}{4}}$
$={3\dfrac{3}{4}}$    Since they cannot buy $\red{\dfrac34}$ of a bag, and they do not have enough money to buy $4$ bags.   So they can buy only $3$ bags.

images.alt: A fraction bar that represents one whole. it is shaded green with the label of 1 below it.
A fraction bar that represents one whole. it is shaded green with the label of 1 below it.
A fraction bar that represents one whole. it is shaded green with the label of 1 below it.
A fraction bar divided into four equal sized pieces with three pieces shaded green. A red X is on top of the bar. Below is the fraction three-fourths written in red.

hints.content: The largest number they can buy is $3$ bags of popcorn.

question.content: $6$ friends are at a pizzeria. They want to order enough pizza so that each person can eat at least $\dfrac25$ of a pizza.  **What is the least number of pizzas the friends should order?**

hints.content: There are $\blue6$ people. Each person wants to eat at least $\red{\dfrac25}$ of a pizza.  Person $\blue1$ | Person $\blue2$ | Person $\blue3$ | Person $\blue4$ |   Person $\blue5$ |  Person $\blue6$     :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  |  | |||  We can multiply $\blue6 \times\red{\dfrac25}$ to figure out how many pizzas they should order.

images.alt: Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.
Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.
Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.
Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.
Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.
Circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded. Circle is labeled two-fifths.

hints.content: $\quad{\blue6 \times} \red{\dfrac25}$  $=\dfrac{{\blue6 \times }\:\red 2} {\red5}$  $={\dfrac{12}{5}}$
$={2\dfrac{2}{5}}$    They cannot order $\dfrac25$ of a pizza, and they will not have enough for everyone if they only order $2$ pizzas.  So they must order $3$ whole pizzas.

images.alt: A circle divided into five equal parts with all parts shaded red. Under the circle is the label 1.
A circle divided into five equal parts with all parts shaded red. Under the circle is the label 1.
A circle divided into five equal parts with two parts shaded red. Under the circle is the label two-fifths.

hints.content: The least number of pizzas they should order is $3$ pizzas.

question.content: There will be $6$ people at Ellie's pie party. She wants to bake enough pie so that each person can eat at least $\dfrac15$ of a pie.   **What is the least number of pies Ellie should bake?**

hints.content: There are $\blue6$ people. Each person will eat at least $\red{\dfrac15}$ of a pie.  Person $\blue1$ | Person $\blue2$ | Person $\blue3$ | Person $\blue4$ | Person $\blue5$  | Person $\blue6$   :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  |  | |||

images.alt: Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth.
Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth.
Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth.
Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth
Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth.
Circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded. Circle is labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: We can multiply $\blue6 \times\red{\dfrac15}$ to figure out how many pies Ellie should bake.
$\quad{\blue6 \times} \red{\dfrac15}$  $=\dfrac{{\blue6 \times }\:\red 1} {\red5}$  $={\dfrac{6}{5}}$
$={1\dfrac{1}{5}}$    Ellie cannot bake $\dfrac15$ of a pie, and there will not be enough pie for everyone if she only bakes $1$ pie.  So Ellie must bake $2$ whole pies.

images.alt: A circle divided into five equal parts with all parts shaded red. The label 1 appears under the circle in red.
A circle divided into five equal parts with one part shaded red. The label of one-fifth in red is under the circle.

hints.content: The least number of pies Ellie should bake is $2$ pies.

question.content: Takeru has $4$ birdfeeders. It takes $\dfrac43$ bags of birdseed to fill each feeder.  **What is the fewest number of bags of birdseed that Takeru needs to fill all the feeders?**

hints.content: There are $\blueD4$ bird feeders. Each bird feeder holds $\greenD{\dfrac43}$ bags of birdseed.  Feeder $\blue1$ | Feeder $\blue2$  | Feeder $\blue3$ | Feeder $\blue4$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   |  |  |   We can multiply $\blueD4 \times\greenD{\dfrac43}$ to figure out how many bags of birdseed Takeru needs to fill all the feeders.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all three parts shaded green. Below the bar is the label three-thirds. Above the bar is the label Feeder 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with one part shaded green. Under the bar is the label one-third. It is also under the label of Feeder 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all three parts shaded green. Below the bar is the label three-thirds. Above the bar is the label Feeder 2.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with one part shaded green. Under the bar is the label one-third. It is also under the label of Feeder 2.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all three parts shaded green. Below the bar is the label three-thirds. Above the bar is the label Feeder 3.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with one part shaded green. Under the bar is the label one-third. It is also under the label of Feeder 3.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all three parts shaded green. Below the bar is the label three-thirds. Above the bar is the label Feeder 4.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with one part shaded green. Under the bar is the label one-third. It is also under the label of Feeder 4.

hints.content: ${\blueD4 \times} \greenD{\dfrac43}=\dfrac{{\blueD4 \times }\:\greenD4} {\greenD3}={\dfrac{16}{3}}$
$={5\dfrac{1}{3}}$    Takeru cannot buy $\dfrac13$ of a bag of birdseed, and the feeders will not all be full if he only uses $5$ bags.  So Takeru must buy $6$ whole bags.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all parts shaded green. Under the bar is the label 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all parts shaded green. Under the bar is the label 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all parts shaded green. Under the bar is the label 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all parts shaded green. Under the bar is the label 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with all parts shaded green. Under the bar is the label 1.
A fraction bar divided into three equal parts with one part shaded green. Under the bar is the label one-third.

hints.content: Takeru needs at least $6$ bags of birdseed.

question.content: Dayton has $3$ bags of frozen  vegetables. Each bag is $\dfrac58$ full of vegetables. He plans to make vegetable soup. Each pot of soup takes $1$ full bag of vegetables.    **How many full pots of soup can Dayton make?**

hints.content: There are $\blueD3$ bags of frozen vegetables. Each bag is $\greenD{\dfrac58}$ full of vegetables.  Bag $\blue1$ | Bag $\blue2$  | Bag $\blue3$  :-: |:-: |:-:   |  |    We can multiply $\blueD3 \times\green{\dfrac58}$ to figure out how many pots of soup Dayton can make.

images.alt: Rectangle divided into 8 equal parts with 5 parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled five-eighths.
Rectangle divided into 8 equal parts with 5 parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled five-eighths.
Rectangle divided into 8 equal parts with 5 parts shaded. Rectangle is labeled five-eighths.

hints.content: ${\blueD3 \times} \greenD{\dfrac58}=\dfrac{{\blueD3 \times }\:\greenD5} {\greenD8}={\dfrac{15}{8}}$
$={1\dfrac{7}{8}}$    Dayton cannot make a full pot of soup with $\dfrac78$ of a bag of vegetables. He can only make $1$ full pot of soup.

images.alt: A fraction bar divided into eight equal-sized parts with all eight parts shaded green. The bar is labeled 1.
A fraction bar divided into eight equal-sized parts with seven parts shaded green. A large red letter X is over the fraction bar. The bar is labeled seven-eighths.

hints.content: Dayton can make $1$ full pot of soup.

question.content: Mina has $\dfrac{4}{5}$ of the flour that she needs to make $12$ rolls.  **What is the greatest number of rolls Mina can make with the flour she has?**

hints.content: Mina has $\purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ of the flour she needs for $\blueE{12}$ rolls.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueE{12}\times \purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}}$ to find out how many rolls Mina can make.

images.alt: Two stacked fractions bars. The top bar is divided into 5 equal parts and has a curved bracket labeled Flour to make 12 rolls. The second bar is the length of the first 4 parts of the top bar. It is labeled four-fifths and has a curved bracket below it labeled Flour Mina has.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueE{12} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueE{12} \times \purpleD{4}}{\purpleD{5}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{48}{5} \end{align}$
Since it doesn't make sense to make part of a roll, Mina can only make $9$ rolls with the flour she has.

question.content: Jim has $\dfrac{7}{10}$ of the sugar that he needs to make $24$ cupcakes.  **What is the greatest number of cupcakes that Jim can make with the sugar he has?**

hints.content: Jim has $\purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}}$ of the sugar he needs for $\blueE{24}$ cupcakes.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueE{24}\times \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}}$ to find out how many cupcakes Jim can make.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars. The top bar is divided into 10 equal parts and has a curved bracket labeled Sugar to make 24 cupcakes. The second bar is the length of the first 7 parts of the top bar. It is labeled seven-tenths and has a curved bracket below it labeled Sugar Jim has.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueE{24} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueE{24} \times \purpleD{7}}{\purpleD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{168}{10} \end{align}$
Since it doesn't make sense to make part of a cupcake, Jim can only make $16$ cupcakes with the sugar he has.

question.content: Nicole has $\dfrac{2}{3}$ of the butter she needs to make $14$ mini pies.  **What is the greatest number of mini pies that Nicole can make with the butter she has?**

hints.content: Nicole has $\purpleD{\dfrac{2}{3}}$ of the butter she needs for $\blueE{14}$ mini pies.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueE{14}\times \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{3}}$ to find out how many mini pies Nicole can make.

images.alt: Two stacked fraction bars. The top bar is divided into 3 parts and is shaded blue with a curved bracket labeled Butter to make 14 mini pies. The second bar is the length of the first 2 parts of the top bar. It is labeled two-thirds and is shaded purple with a curved bracket below it labeled Butter Nicole has.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\phantom{=}\blueE{14} \times \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{3}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueE{14} \times \purpleD{2}}{\purpleD{3}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{28}{3} \end{align}$
$= 9\dfrac13$
Since it doesn't make sense to make part of a mini pie, the greatest number of mini pies Nicole can make is $9$.
